data.title: In debug mode user should not get context menu and value pop-up (datatips on hover) together.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version:Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open any .ts project.
2. Set configuration for tasks.json, Launch.json and tsconfig,json.
3. Set the break point and start debugging.
4. Once break point hit then mouse over on a variable to get info.
5. Verify info and right click at the same position.
6. Verify app behavior.

Actual: Variable value and context info options are displaying together.
Expected: When user perform right click then pop-up to display value of the variable(datatips on mouse hover) should go away. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14452122/49eca8f2-0041-11e6-9ab6-9a1500dcf8d7.png)

data.title: How to debug node global command
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: windows 10 pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  In my case I use webpack to do code load and package, now I added a plugin to do sth, how should I do with vscode to debug this plugin
2.  To run the command I need to locate the cmd at the project folder, and in the cmd run 'webpack' command

so webpack is install in the global and the plugin is in the project folder, I was confuse how to set the launch.js to support my case? 

Thanks.

data.title: User should get "Build success" message when build is successful.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch VS code and open any folder which contains .ts file.
2. Configure tasks.json and tsconfig.json files.
3. Set "showOutput": "always" setting into tasks.json.
4. Perform build operation and verify error or success message in the output window.

Actual: Getting proper message when there is any build error but not getting any message when build is successful.
Expected: When build is successful user should get the "Build success" message something similar to Visual Studio.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14449052/ebf2cf3c-0023-11e6-96f4-1f234a02eeed.png)

data.title: optimize postinstall
data.body: Optimize postinstall script in package.json. Make it read comfortably.

data.title: Update setup dialog defaults to English
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install an old build or wait for an update
2. Change language from English to any other supported language
3. Update

Actual:
The setup or install dialog that shows up is in English. 

Expected:
During initial setup you can select the language you would like to use for setup. I think the update setup dialog should be based off the current language setting in Code.

data.title: Installing should default first launch to selected language
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Windows 10
- OS Version: 1.0.0-alpha

Steps to Reproduce:
1. If you have VS Code installed, uninstall.
2. Run setup
3. Select another language (apart from English)
4. Launch after setup

Actual:
VS Code is launched in English (or if you have previously set the language, it will launch in that)

Expected:
By default it should launch in the language you selected during install.

data.title: Open Change option should not show for files without changes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Right click on a file in the Git menu that is untracked or deleted 
2. Clicking on show changes does nothing.

It would be nice, if possible, to not show the option for open change if there is no change to show.

data.title: JS `var` syntax highlighting leaks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.3

JS syntax highlighting for `var` and `let` leaks into some words that contain these patterns:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5997332/14443263/0773c3c8-fff3-11e5-9f7d-70fea8387e71.png)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a file using either `JavaScript` or `JavaScript React` syntax highlighting.
2. Use `Dark (Visual Studio)` theme, or any theme with `var` and `let` highlighting.
3. Observe the following code's syntax highlighting:

```
var // correct

variable // incorrect

var
variable // incorrect

var // random comment
variable // correct

var;
variable // incorrect

const // correct
constant // correct

let // correct

lettuce // incorrect

let // random comment
lettuce // correct

let;
lettuce // incorrect

sublet // correct
```

data.title: Ruby def/end should highlight the same as brackets
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

When you click on or next to an opening or closing bracket it highlights the other. In Ruby it would be nice if selecting near a def or end highlighted/outlined the respective open/closing one.

data.title: Can't rename a folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version:0.10.11
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open powershell and cd to a existing project folder
2. run "code ."
3. Try to rename an existing folder

VSCode return an error "Operation not permtited".

data.title: Tab Order for "Replace" doesn't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.6
- OS Version: Windows 10 10.0.10240.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a text file open
2. Press Ctrl+H
3. The "Replace" text box is in focus
4. Press "Tab" at least 3 times.

Observed behavior: There is no way to get to the "Find" box from just tab order.  It occurred to me that Ctrl+F will get there, but that's definitely not obvious and not in keeping with usual mechanisms.

data.title: Can't add predefined launch configurations with the menu to an existing launch.json file
data.body:
A user reported this issue to us: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-react-native/issues/208
While trying to add a predefined launch configuration to an existing launch.json, the button doesn't work as we'd expect it to work.

I think it'd make sense to have a way to add a predefined launch configuration to an existing launch.json file.

data.title: Same User, Multiple Sessions, Instance collision

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Server 2012 R2 6.3 Build 9600

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an RDP session to a server
2. Launch code via opening a file
3. Open another RDP session to a server as the same user
4. Launch code via opening a different file 

The file will open on the already first user session instance of code

data.title: VS Code can not be launched from terminal on Mac
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.4
- Node Version: 5.10.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch code from terminal `code .`. It fails with the following error - 

``` bash
File "<string>", line 1
import os,sys; print os.path.realpath(sys.argv[1])
                          ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
/usr/local/bin/code: line 10: ./MacOS/Electron: No such file or directory
```

It used to work perfectly alright before the OS X upgrade to 10.11.4. Just to be sure, I uninstalled code from PATH and installed it again through command palette but no luck.

data.title: No "in progress" indicator for committing inside editor
data.body:
Feature Request

We have git hooks that run when we want to commit (tsc compile, tslint, and unit test run).

They take a few seconds.

It would be good if there could be a spinner or something when you try to commit from within the editor

data.title: Links on Visual Studio Code Feature Poll page don't work
data.body:
https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/293070-visual-studio-code

Links go to Github and Requested Extensions go to https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/(https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues) and https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/(https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Requested-Extensions) respectively

Maybe a markdown error?

data.title: Certain key combinations are treated wrong in MacOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the 'Advanced New File' extension or create a shortcut that is listening for Mac on `alt+cmd+n`
2. It displays the keyboard shortcut correctly in the command palette
3. It doesn't trigger the respective command.
4. Changing it to `alt+cmd+`` will do the trick and trigger the shortcut when you press <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>Cmd</kbd>+<kbd>N</kbd>

It appears that this is happening because <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>N</kbd> is an actual special character and rather than triggering the actual keys it handles the special characters.

data.title: feature: Add an option to hide private members in Intellisense
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 (64-bit)

It would be great to hide the private members in Intellisense, as in some frameworks/libraries _(e.g. Ionic 2)_ there are a lot of members shown in the Intellisense popup when only few of them are public _(i.e. targeted at the end user)_. This makes the use of Intellisense harder especially at the beginning when exploring a new framework/library or functionality/class for the first time. Now the private members are marked as such _(with `@private`)_ but sometimes it still requires too much scrolling/browsing to find the needed class member in the Intellisense popup.

data.title: node-weak issues with Electron and node 5.x
data.body:
We see native crashes when using node-weak together with latest Electron version (see https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/4299).

Setup VS Code:
- checkout `ben/electron`
- `git clean -xfd`
- `scripts/npm.sh install`
- `gulp watch`
- `scripts/code.sh`
- this should start with Electron 0.37.5 just fine

Setup a workspace to reproduce the crash:
- git clone `https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript.git`
- I can reproduce on https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/commit/94ada07
- open the workspace
- open `lib/dom.generated.d.ts` (or any other large d.ts file they have)
- hover over some of the interfaces to the top (triggers language service)
- open `harness/runner.ts`
- hover over `runTests` to the top to trigger language service
- jump back and forth between these two files (`Cmd+Tab`) and repeat
- eventually you should get the crash (it seems to reproduce more easily after a window reload for some reason)

Things that make it not reproduce:
- disabled git (somehow the git-index resources as models cause issues)
- disabling node-weak
- changing node-weak to always return a fresh weak reference

data.title: No IntelliSense for TS/JS files
data.body:
Hi *,

I try to replace webstorm with vscode as my main development editor/IDE, but as of now its not possible for me. Im not sure if this is a bug or misconfiguration of my system but IntelliSense, "Go to definition" and other useful stuff don't work for JavaScript or TypeScript files. On the other hand "context-aware" JSONs like `tsconfig.json`, `package.json` do work like expected.

This is my test repo: https://github.com/otbe/vscode-intellisense-test

And this happens on my (and only on my) machine:
![no-intellisense](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3391052/14424337/d419dbc8-ffe0-11e5-9539-b8cd4f0b3828.gif)

I have made no changes to the default settings of vscode.

Grateful for every hint :/
Thanks.

Versions:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.14-insider | 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.3

data.title: [ruby] add support for non-interpolated (and others) heredoc syntax

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11.
- OS Version: Windows 10.

Currently Code supports the Here Documents (aka heredoc) using this syntax:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/43356/14420605/e8df4f46-ffc4-11e5-8a74-3ab0657b1be8.png)

But the following are not supported:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/43356/14420640/16de0734-ffc5-11e5-828f-4e134bb84441.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/43356/14420654/2e565f10-ffc5-11e5-9e73-e765b73ee56f.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/43356/14420686/55c2d0b0-ffc5-11e5-9db9-e0d135206c4f.png)

See the exact details about the [Here Documents at the Ruby Manual](http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.2.0/doc/syntax/literals_rdoc.html#label-Here+Documents) and also [other examples](http://makandracards.com/makandra/15003-how-to-ruby-heredoc-without-interpolation).

data.title: Fonts are rendered with blur when "jumping" to some text.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press "Ctrl + =" to zoom in the view.
2. Search for some text
3. Click "F3" to jump to the "Next match"

The fonts are rendered with blur.
![screen_blur](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6037811/14419649/cef9e610-fff9-11e5-8941-dde568c84570.png)

If I pressed "Ctrl+Home" to "reset" the rendering, then use mouse to scroll to that line, the fonts are clear and sharp.
![screen_clear](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6037811/14419651/d2130afc-fff9-11e5-9fa5-da68d839d603.png)

The details of the fonts are as below:
blur:
![blur_detail](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6037811/14419664/eff0d0f4-fff9-11e5-9d31-9a18f4ab6ef2.png)

sharp:
![clear_detail](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6037811/14419671/fca5f842-fff9-11e5-8192-4d8ee3bd89c8.png)

It seems the **height** of blurred font is **16px**, and the "normal" font is **15px**.

Because the monitor in my company is 22" 1920*1080, the default font size of VSCode is too small. Though we can modify the "editor.fontSize" setting, but the font-size of side bar will still be very small, so I think zoom in once is the most comfortable way to make text easy to read...if without this issue.

And I think it's not a duplicate of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4622.

data.title: Extension host only modules gets loaded in renderer side
data.body:
extHostDocuments requires "weak" even though this module is only used in the extension host side it gets loaded from the renderer side because of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/electron-browser/shell.ts#L49

Imho we should do a clean split between modules needed for API that get loaded on the renderer side vs. extension host side. Otherwise it is easy to accidentally sneak in modules into the renderer. We should stay away from that because module loading slows down startup.

data.title: Starting VSCode with a non-English layout and then switching to English
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Switch to non-English keyboard layout (in my case German)
2. Start VSCode
3. Switch to U.S. keyboard layout
4. Hit CMD+/
5. Nothing happens, even though this should comment / uncomment
6. Switch back to German keyboard layout
7. Hit CMD+- ('-' (dash) on the German keyboard layout is in the same location as '/' (slash) on the U.S. keyboard layout)
8. Now you get comment / uncomment

Possibly related issues: #4619, #1549, #1492
